question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Each of the following statements correctly describes metallic compounds in the solid state EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: They are brittle

options.label: B.
options.text: They are ductile

options.label: C.
options.text: They are malleable

options.label: D.
options.text: They can be hammered into sheets

options.label: E.
options.text: They are good conductors of electricity

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving metallic compounds , we will first go over their properties: In this case, we can see that metallic compounds in the solid state are not brittle (Option A). Brittle objects tend to shatter easily and are usually characteristic of ionic compounds, not metallic compounds. Therefore, the answer is A .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Ionic compounds are great conductors of electricity dissolved in an aqueous solution. Which statement best explains this phenomenon?

options.label: A.
options.text: An extensive sea of electrons is released in solution

options.label: B.
options.text: Water is a conducting polar covalent compound

options.label: C.
options.text: Ionic compounds dissociate into component ions

options.label: D.
options.text: The ionic bonds form a conductive chain in solution

options.label: E.
options.text: Crystalline lattices are formed with water molecules

correct_answer_text: Ionic compounds dissociate into component ions

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving ionic compounds , we can recall that when ionic compounds are dissolved in aqueous solutions, they dissociate into their component cations and anions. These ions make their aqueous solutions great conductors of electricity because they help relay electric currents due to their mobility in the aqueous solution. In contrast, when an ionic compound is in its solid state, it is a poor conductor because the ions are fixed in place and cannot move to relay electric currents. In this case, we can say that ionic compounds are great conductors of electricity in aqueous solutions because ionic compounds dissociate into component ions . Therefore, the answer is C .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Which of the following statements best distinguishes between ionic and covalent compounds?

options.label: A.
options.text: Ionic compounds are formed between nonmetals, covalent compounds are formed between metals and nonmetals

options.label: B.
options.text: Ionic compounds share electrons, covalent compounds transfer electrons

options.label: C.
options.text: Ionic compounds are insulators, covalent compounds have high conductivity in solution

options.label: D.
options.text: Ionic compounds are usually soluble in water, covalent compounds usually are not

options.label: E.
options.text: Ionic compounds have a molecular structure, covalent compounds have a lattice structure

correct_answer_text: Ionic compounds are usually soluble in water, covalent compounds usually are not

explanation.concept_text: Option A. Ionic compounds are formed between nonmetals, covalent compounds are formed between metals and nonmetals Incorrect. Ionic compounds are formed between metals and nonmetals , covalent compounds are formed between nonmetals . Option B. Ionic compounds share electrons, covalent compounds transfer electrons Incorrect. Ionic compounds transfer electrons, covalent compounds share electrons. Option C. Ionic compounds are insulators, covalent compounds have high conductivity in solution Incorrect. Ionic compounds are conductors , covalent compounds are insulators (low conductivity) in solution. Option D. Ionic compounds are usually soluble in water, covalent compounds usually are not Correct. Ionic compounds readily dissolve in water, dissociating into their component cations and anions. Covalent compounds are bonded covalently, which means they do not readily dissolve and dissociate in solution. Option E. Ionic compounds have a molecular structure, covalent compounds have a lattice structure Incorrect. Ionic compounds have lattice structure , covalent compounds have molecular structure . Therefore, the answer is D .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: When compared to metallic compounds, ionic compounds are more

options.label: A.
options.text: ductile.

options.label: B.
options.text: malleable.

options.label: C.
options.text: lustrous.

options.label: D.
options.text: brittle.

options.label: E.
options.text: flexible.

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving metallic compounds vs. ionic compounds , we will first go over the properties of metallic compounds: and the properties of ionic compounds: In this case, we can say that when compared to metallic compounds, ionic compounds are more brittle (shatter easily). Ionic compounds are composed of cations and anions in a regular lattice. When ionic compounds are disrupted, the component ions shift, which brings cations in close proximity of other cations, resulting in electrostatic repulsion that breaks apart the compound. The same can be said about anions in the ionic compound, which explains why ionic compounds are brittle. The other properties (ductile, malleable, lustrous, flexible) are all characteristic of metallic compounds. Therefore, the answer is D .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Which of the following statements best explains why ionic compounds are brittle and metallic compounds are malleable?

options.label: A.
options.text: They differ in their size

options.label: B.
options.text: They differ in their conductivity

options.label: C.
options.text: They differ in their bond strength

options.label: D.
options.text: They differ in their bond length

options.label: E.
options.text: They differ in their arrangement of ions

correct_answer_text: They differ in their arrangement of ions

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving ionic compounds vs. metallic compounds , let’s first recall that ionic compounds are brittle (shatter easily) because they are composed of cations and anions in a regular lattice structure. When ionic compounds are disrupted, the component ions shift, which brings cations in close proximity of other cations, resulting in electrostatic repulsion that breaks apart the compound. The same can be said about anions in the ionic compound, which explains why ionic compounds are brittle. Meanwhile, metallic compounds are malleable (can be hammered into thin sheets) because their structure is composed of metallic cations in a “sea” of delocalized electrons. When metallic compounds are “hit”, the metallic structure is simply deformed. In this case, we can say that ionic compounds are brittle and metallic compounds are malleable because they differ in their arrangement of ions . Therefore, the answer is E .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Both diamond and graphite are composed of pure carbon atoms. Which of the following best explains why diamond is a harder substance?

options.label: A.
options.text: Diamond is connected by ionic bonds, graphite is connected by covalent bonds

options.label: B.
options.text: Diamond has an extensive network of covalent bonds, graphite has layered rings

options.label: C.
options.text: Diamond is made of pure carbon atoms, graphite has carbon and impurities

options.label: D.
options.text: Diamond has smaller carbon atoms, graphite has larger, bulky carbon atoms

options.label: E.
options.text: Diamond is made of alternating carbon cations and anions, graphite is not

correct_answer_text: Diamond has an extensive network of covalent bonds, graphite has layered rings

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving covalent compounds , let’s first discuss the different molecular structure of diamond and graphite: In this case, we can say that diamond is so much harder than graphite because diamond has an extensive network of covalent bonds , while graphite has layered rings . It is notable that both are covalent compounds composed of only carbon atoms. Therefore, the answer is B .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: The structure of a metallic compound can be best described as

options.label: A.
options.text: a crystal lattice.

options.label: B.
options.text: an amorphous substance.

options.label: C.
options.text: a covalent network.

options.label: D.
options.text: an ionic lattice.

options.label: E.
options.text: a random assortment.

explanation.concept_text: Option A. a crystal lattice. Correct. Metallic compounds have highly ordered crystalline structures, characterized by regular and repeating arrangement of metal atoms in a crystal lattice. They have a long-range, predictable molecular structure. Option B. an amorphous substance. Incorrect. Amorphous materials lack the long-range, predictable molecular structures that metallic compounds have. Instead, they are disordered without a pattern. Option C. a covalent network. Incorrect. Covalent networks are more often associated with covalent compounds (such as diamonds), not metallic compounds. Option D. an ionic lattice. Incorrect. Ionic lattices are more often associated with ionic compounds , not metallic compounds. Option E. a random assortment. Incorrect. Metallic compounds are not randomly assorted, because they have a specific structure of cations arranged in a “sea” of delocalized electrons. Therefore, the answer is A .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: What property of metallic compounds allow them to conduct heat exceptionally well?

options.label: A.
options.text: The presence of polar covalent bonds

options.label: B.
options.text: The tendency to form complex crystal structures

options.label: C.
options.text: The sea of negatively-charged electrons

options.label: D.
options.text: The strong ionic compounds between metal ions

options.label: E.
options.text: The molecular symmetry of the crystal lattice

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving metallic compounds , let’s first recall that metallic compounds are composed of cations in a “sea” of delocalized electrons. It is this “sea” of delocalized free-floating electrons that makes metallic compounds able to conduct heat exceptionally well, because the electrons are readily excitable and free to move around. In this case, we can say that metallic compounds can conduct heat exceptionally well because of the sea of negatively-charged electrons . Therefore, the answer is C .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Which of the following generally occurs when covalent compounds are placed in water?

options.label: A.
options.text: Covalent compounds dissociate into component ions

options.label: B.
options.text: Covalent compounds react violently in water

options.label: C.
options.text: Covalent compounds always form hydrogen bonds with water

options.label: D.
options.text: Covalent compounds release a sea of electrons in water

options.label: E.
options.text: Covalent compounds usually do not dissociate in water

correct_answer_text: Covalent compounds usually do not dissociate in water

explanation.concept_text: Option A. Covalent compounds dissociate into component ions Incorrect. This is a property of an ionic compound , which dissociates into component ions. Recall that in covalent compounds, electrons are shared , not transferred like in ionic compounds, so there are no component ions in covalent compounds. Option B. Covalent compounds react violently in water Incorrect. While some covalent compounds may react violently in water, it is not a generally observed phenomenon. Option C. Covalent compounds always form hydrogen bonds with water Incorrect. While some covalent compounds can form hydrogen bonds with water (ex: alcohols, esters, etc.), it is not a generally observed phenomenon. Option D. Covalent compounds release a sea of electrons in water. Incorrect. This is not a generally observed phenomenon with any type of molecule. Option E. Covalent compounds usually do not dissociate in water Correct. Covalent compounds are bonded through shared electrons between two non-metals, which means that they are not composed of the typical component ions we see in ionic compounds. Therefore, when placed in water, they usually do not dissociate. Therefore, the answer is E .

question_bank: Ionic vs. Covalent vs. Metallic Compounds

question.text: Each of the following is a property of KNO 3 EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: A.
options.text: Crystalline solid

options.label: B.
options.text: High melting point

options.label: C.
options.text: Insoluble in water

options.label: D.
options.text: Conducts electricity in aqueous solution

options.label: E.
options.text: High boiling point

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving ionic compounds , we first need to identify that KNO 3 is an ionic compound. KNO 3 is composed of its component cations (K + ) and anions (NO 3 – ) which are ionically bonded together when K donates an electron to NO 3 . Having established that KNO 3 is an ionic compound, let’s review the properties of ionic compounds: In this case, each of the answer choices are properties of ionic compounds except for “ionic compounds are insoluble in water ” (Option C). Just to double check, according to the solubility rules, nitrates (NO 3 – ) and potassium (K + ) are both soluble, so KNO 3 is soluble in water. Therefore, the answer is C .
